awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Emulating Emerging Autonomous Vehicle Technologies to Understand Their Impact on Urban Congestion
awd_abstract_narration:
Self-driving cars are here to stay, and this emerging automated vehicle (AV) technology will transform our transportation system. Potential benefits of AV technology include improved safety and greater capacity for more vehicles to travel on the road (by forming a platoon of vehicles with very close distance with each other).  But how AV technologies will evolve in the future is highly uncertain, and so is our understanding of their impacts on our transportation system. For example, none of the AV models in the literature have been validated with empirical data, which makes existing predictions about their impacts highly questionable. Recent studies on a platoon of Tesla vehicles suggest that traffic congestion might actually increase. To address this problem, this project will conduct measurements using commercially available AV vehicles and come up with mathematical models that replicate their behavior. These models will allow us to better understand how AV vehicles behave when they form a platoon with each other and come up with methods to address undesirable consequences such as congestion. The educational component of this project will expose both undergrad and graduate students to a thriving ecosystem where car manufacturers, technology companies and application developers  foster innovation via open source software, learning material and data sets to train the machine learning models needed for AV technologies.

The research objective of this project is to develop an analytical and numerical framework to emulate the impacts that current AV technologies will have on the transportation networks of the near future. The research approach will be based on the collection of large amounts of empirical data from Level 2/3 AVs currently on the market to train the type of machine learning models that the industry is implementing, consisting of a combination of deep neural networks and expert domain knowledge. Given the recent empirical evidence revealing that these vehicles may exhibit more string instability than human drivers, the project will identify stability constraints that can be incorporated during training to avoid instability. Additionally, the corresponding car-following models that will establish macroscopic dynamics at the network level will be formulated. The project will focus on the longitudinal acceleration/deceleration component since it plays the major role in string stability, network capacity and congestion. It also makes it possible to train machine learning models with a fraction of the data needed for general scenarios, and understanding this simplified driving scenario is the first step towards a successful analysis of more general cases. The impact of this project is expected to be significant as it will establish the connection between machine learning models and car-following models, and will steer research and development of future AV technologies towards artificial intelligence models that are guaranteed to be stable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In an era where autonomous vehicles (AVs) are becoming increasingly prevalent, our project embarked on a critical examination of Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) systems, a cornerstone technology in the development of self-driving cars. Our research aimed to understand the impacts of ACC on traffic flow and congestion, with a focus on string stability—a measure of how traffic oscillations are amplified or dampened across vehicles in a line.

 

Empirical Insights into ACC Performance

Our investigation began with the collection and analysis of empirical trajectory data from commercial ACC-equipped vehicles; see Figure 1 a). This comprehensive analysis revealed a critical finding: most ACC systems are string unstable; see Figure 1b). This instability means that minor speed adjustments by one vehicle can lead to amplified stop-and-go traffic waves, exacerbating congestion and potentially leading to safety hazards. Such behavior challenges the notion that ACC systems inherently improve traffic flow and efficiency.

 

 

 

Figure 1. a) empirical testing of commercial ACC systems on the road; b) string unstable vehicle trajectories collected from Tesla Autopilot platoons

 

Moreover, our research uncovered that ACC-equipped vehicles could, under certain conditions, significantly alter the fundamental dynamics of traffic flow. For instance, at minimal headway settings, we observed capacities exceeding 3500 vehicles per hour and equilibrium wave speeds of up to 100 kilometers per hour—figures that starkly contrast with traditional human-driven traffic patterns. These findings suggest that while ACC technologies promise enhanced safety and efficiency, they also introduce new dynamics that must be carefully managed to avoid unintended consequences on road networks.

 

Innovative Solutions for Enhanced Traffic Flow

Building upon these insights, our team delved into the underlying mechanisms of ACC's impact on congestion. We discovered that the low-level control systems of ACC play a pivotal role in string stability. By analyzing open-source ACC systems, we identified opportunities for fine-tuning these controls to mitigate adverse effects on traffic flow, such as those caused by environmental disturbances like road grades or winds.

 

To address the challenges identified, our project proposed several innovative ACC designs. These new models draw inspiration from both human driving behaviors and established car-following models, incorporating elements like driver relaxation and anticipation. Notably, we developed a new family of Model Predictive Controllers (MPCs) based on Newell’s car-following model, offering a robust solution for achieving string stability without the complexities associated with predictive tasks. These designs have been experimentally validated on the road, see Figure 2; demonstrating their potential to harmonize with existing ACC technologies while significantly reducing congestion.

 

 

Figure 2. Implementation of our control design in commercial ACC vehicles on the road

 

Key Outcomes and Broader Impacts

Our project has yielded several key outcomes:

  1. We provided empirical evidence on how current commercial ACC products can amplify traffic congestion, challenging existing perceptions of their benefits.
  2. We extended traffic flow theory to account for the significant impact of low-level control on ACC’s string stability, offering a deeper understanding of how these systems interact with traffic dynamics.
  3. We proposed and tested new ACC designs that promise to improve traffic flow by learning from effective human driving behaviors and established traffic flow models.

 

Conclusion

 

Our research offers critical insights into the complex dynamics introduced by ACC systems in autonomous vehicles, highlighting both challenges and opportunities for the future of transportation. By advancing our understanding of these technologies and proposing innovative solutions, we aim to contribute to the development of safer, more efficient, and less congested roadways. As we move forward, our findings and innovations stand to inform both the evolution of autonomous vehicle technologies and the broader efforts to enhance traffic management and urban mobility.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2024
Modified by: Jorge A Laval
